text: when the Warriors was first released it
was immediately popular with young
audiences now it's a cult classic which
raises an interesting question how can
something that looks at first glance
like a pop culture throwaway turn out to
be so durable can you dig it directed by
Walter Hill and adapted from a novel by
Saul Urich
the Warriors takes place in a violent
and dystopian landscape that looks an
awful lot like New York City in 1970
warriors are a gang from Coney Island
and they travel to the Bronx for a big
citywide gang summit when things go
terribly wrong a bounty is placed on
their heads and their return to Brooklyn
becomes an epic journey I think we chef
Cyrus what are you talking about I don't
get it I think we shot Cyrus every gang
the city must be looking for us running
commentary is provided by an unseen
radio DJ as the Warriors confront rival
gangs the orphans the robes the punks
the baseball Furies the Gramercy riffs
the lizzi's and the NYPD
Walter Hill is a great action director
and the fight scenes and the Warriors
play like inspired dance numbers
the movie is colorful fast-moving
visually witty and as lean as a 50s be
Western warriors has some of the appeal
of a great comic book it embraces its
own camp eNOS even as it takes its
characters of their emotions very
seriously and avoids the pretentiousness
that plagues so many comic books based
superhero movies
[Music]
the story has an even older source an
ancient Greek epic called the Anabasis
by Xena fog which relates the adventures
of a Greek army stranded deep in enemy
Persian territory and this was an
explicit source both for Walter Hill and
for Saul Urich in his mob the reason
that the Warriors has endured is that it
belongs completely to its moment even as
it draws its power from a story as old
as time itself
